choices.text: Adenomyosis
Contraception
Endometrial hyperplasia
Asymptomatic fibroid uterus

questions.text: The LNG-IUS system as shown below can be used for all the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Asymptomatic fibroid uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Mirena is a type of Levonorgestrel – Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)
  • It contains levonorgestrel – 52 mg in total with a release rate of 20μg/ day
  • Effective life: 5 years
  • Uses: 
    • Contraception
    • Non contraceptive uses (Mnemonic: Mirena Safekeeps Endangered Animals)
      • Endometriosis
      • Symptomatic fibroid (not distorting the cavity)
      • Endometrial hyperplasia
      • Adenomyosis
  • There is no indication for use of LNG-IUS in an asymptomatic fibroid
  • Contraindications to Mirena:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis
    • Puerperal sepsis
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Cervical cancer
    • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Current Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Genital Tuberculosis
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity
    • Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis is a condition where the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) breaks through the muscle wall of the uterus. The LNG-IUS releases hormones that can thin the endometrial lining, reducing the symptoms of adenomyosis, such as heavy menstrual bleeding and pain.

 

Option B. Contraception: One of the primary uses of LNG-IUS is contraception. It works by releasing levonorgestrel, a progestin, which thickens the cervical mucus to prevent sperm from reaching an egg, thins the lining of the uterus, and partially suppresses ovulation.

 

Option C. Endometrial Hyperplasia: LNG-IUS is used in the treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, a condition where the lining of the uterus becomes too thick. It is especially beneficial in cases without atypia, as it can reduce the proliferation of the endometrial cells, thereby reducing the risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Asymptomatic Fibroid Uterus (Correct Answer): While LNG-IUS can help in managing symptoms of uterine fibroids such as heavy menstrual bleeding, but it does not have effect on the size reduction. hence its role is limited in asymptomatic fibroid. In asymptomatic fibroid, the goal is to reduce size of fibroid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirena is a type of Levonorgestrel – Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)
  • It contains levonorgestrel – 52 mg in total with a release rate of 20μg/ day
  • Effective life: 5 years
  • Uses: 
    • Contraception
    • Non contraceptive uses (Mnemonic: Mirena Safekeeps Endangered Animals)
      • Endometriosis
      • Symptomatic fibroid (not distorting the cavity)
      • Endometrial hyperplasia
      • Adenomyosis
  • There is no indication for use of LNG-IUS in an asymptomatic fibroid
  • Contraindications to Mirena:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis
    • Puerperal sepsis
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Cervical cancer
    • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Current Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Genital Tuberculosis
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity
    • Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Ref: Page no 272, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition

choices.text: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate
Vaginal contraceptive ring
Progestin implants
Ulipristal acetate

questions.text: A 19y unmarried nulliparous girl comes to the OPD. She is sexually active and wants to know more about the contraceptive options available to her. All can be recommended to her except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Ulipristal acetate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Contraceptive of choice in adolescents is dual method i.e condom + any other form of contraception (Condom prevents against STI’s)
  • Methods commonly used in adolescence:
    • Barrier (male condom, female condom)
    • Hormonal contraception:
      • Combined OCPs
      • Extended cyclic pills
      • Progestin only pills
      • Transdermal patches
      • Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring)
      • Injectable hormonal contraceptives
        • DMPA
      • Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant)
    • Intra-Uterine Devices

 

Ulipristal acetate is a Selective Progesterone Receptor Modulator and is used as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

  • Option A: Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA): This is an injectable form of contraception that is administered every three months. It is a progestin-only method, making it suitable for women who may not be able to use estrogen-containing contraceptives. DMPA is highly effective and convenient for those who prefer not to take a daily pill.
  • Option B: Vaginal Contraceptive Ring: The vaginal ring is a small, flexible ring that a woman inserts into her vagina. It releases estrogen and progestin, similar to combination oral contraceptives, but requires less frequent attention as it is typically changed monthly. It is a convenient and effective form of contraception.
  • Option C: Progestin Implants: These are small rods implanted under the skin of the arm that release a steady dose of progestin. They can provide long-term contraception for up to three to five years. The implant is a highly effective, low-maintenance option.
  • Option D: Ulipristal Acetate (Correct Answer): Ulipristal acetate is used as an emergency contraceptive, not a regular method of contraception. It is intended for use after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure (like a broken condom) to prevent pregnancy. It's not designed for ongoing, regular use as a contraceptive method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When advising a sexually active young woman on contraceptive options, it is important to discuss a range of choices, including hormonal methods like depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injections, vaginal contraceptive rings, and progestin implants. Each of these offers long-term contraception with varying administration methods to suit different preferences. Ulipristal acetate, however, is an emergency contraceptive and is not suitable for regular contraceptive use.

 

Ref: Page no 279, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition

choices.text: To reapply the patch with another adhesive
To apply a new patch
To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week
To remove the patch and use a condom till her next period

questions.text: A 23y woman has been using the transdermal patch as a contraceptive method. She visits the OPD with the complaint that the patch was partially detached for more than a day. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

 

Explanation:

 

  • If the patch was detached for less than 24 h, the same patch can be reattached or a replaced with a new one.
  • If a patch is partially or completely detached for more than one day (24 hours or more) OR if the woman is not sure how long the patch has been detached, she may not be protected from pregnancy. She should stop the current contraceptive cycle and start a new cycle immediately by applying a new patch. Back-up contraception, such as a condom, spermicide, or diaphragm, must be used for the first week of the new cycle.

 

Educational Objective: In cases where the contraceptive patch has been detached for more than 24 hours, it is important to apply a new patch immediately and use a backup method of contraception, such as condoms, for the next 7 days. This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while accounting for any period during which the effectiveness of the patch may have been compromised.

 

Ref: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2011/021180s038lbl.pdf, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition page122

choices.text: Implanon
Minipill
LNG-IUS
Nuva-ring

questions.text: All the following can be given as contraceptives in a lactating mother except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Nuva-ring

 

Explanation:

 

  • In lactating women, Estrogen containing contraceptives are not preferred to be given as they reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk.
  • Progesterone containing contraceptives and non – hormonal contraceptives can be safely given.
  • Amongst the given options
    • Implanon – contains etonorgestrel
    • Minipill – contains progesterone (Norethisterone OR Levonorgestrel OR Desogestrel)
    • LNG-IUS contains Levonorgestrel
    • Nuva Ring – contains both Estrogen and Progesterone (ethinyl estradiol and etonorgestrel)

 

Let's review each option:

 

  • Option A: Implanon (Nexplanon): Implanon is a progestin-only contraceptive implant that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a small amount of hormone over time. Progestin-only methods are generally considered safe for use during lactation as they have minimal effect on milk production and are unlikely to harm the nursing infant.
  • Option B. Minipill: The minipill is a progestin-only oral contraceptive. Like Implanon, it is generally safe for use during breastfeeding. The progestin-only formulation is less likely to affect milk supply compared to combined oral contraceptives that contain both estrogen and progestin.
  • Option C: LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System): The LNG-IUS, like Mirena, releases levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, and is inserted into the uterus. It is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers as it has minimal systemic hormonal effects and primarily acts locally on the uterine lining.
  • Option D: NuvaRing (Correct Answer): The NuvaRing is a combined hormonal contraceptive that contains both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are typically not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially in the early postpartum period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For lactating mothers (< 6 months post-partum), estrogen containing contraceptives are contra-indicated.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition , page 106

choices.text: Stop breastfeeding
Take the tablet at the same time everyday
Use barrier contraception also
It can be used as emergency contraception

questions.text: A 20 y P2L2 who delivered 2 months back has decided to take progesterone only pill as a contraceptive. What important advice should be given?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Take the tablet at the same time everyday

 

Explanation

 

  • Progesterone only pills (POP) are also known as mini-pills
  • They can be started after delivery in lactating/ non lactating women or within the first 5 days (preferably 1st day) of the periods.
  • POPs are safe in lactation. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) containing both estrogen (E) and progesterone (P) reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk and thus are contraindicated in lactation
  • Mini pills are best taken at the same time everyday.
  • If there is a dose delay of > 3 h, a backup method should be used for 48h but for desogestrel (Cerazette) containing POPs, the safety margin is 12 hours
  • No other contraceptive is required with POP unless there has been a dose delay.
  • It cannot be used as an emergency contraception. High dose OCPs (E + P) can be used as emergency contraception.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

  • Option A: Stop Breastfeeding: This advice is not appropriate. The progesterone-only pill is actually a preferred choice for breastfeeding mothers because it does not affect milk supply as estrogen-containing contraceptives can. It is safe to use while breastfeeding.
  • Option B: Take the Tablet at the Same Time Every Day (Correct Answer): This is crucial advice for a woman taking the progesterone-only pill. The effectiveness of the POP depends on consistent daily intake at the same time each day. The time window for taking the POP is narrower than for combined oral contraceptives; a delay of even a few hours can decrease its effectiveness and increase the risk of pregnancy.
  • Option C: Use Barrier Contraception Also: While using barrier methods in addition can provide extra protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), it is not a requirement for the effectiveness of the POP.
  • Option D: It Can be Used as Emergency Contraception: The regular progesterone-only pill is not intended for use as emergency contraception. There are specific emergency contraceptive pills available for that purpose.

 

Educational Objective: For a woman taking the progesterone-only contraceptive pill, it is essential to take the pill at the same time every day to maintain its contraceptive effectiveness. The POP is a suitable choice for breastfeeding mothers as it does not affect milk supply and is safe for the baby. It is not used as emergency contraception, and while barrier methods can be used alongside for added protection and STI prevention, they are not necessary for the effectiveness of the pill itself.

 

Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH
Destroying the ovum
Helping prevent implantation by suppressing development of the endometrium
Hampering sperm transport by thickening cervical mucus

questions.text: The primary mechanism of action of the Combined Oral Contraceptives is:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH 

 

Explanation

 

  • The main action of combined oral contraceptives is:
    • Ovulation suppression: Most important
  • Other effects
    • Endometrial atrophy
    • Cervical mucus thickening
    • Alteration of ovum transport

 

Since the main mechanism of action is asked; the answer is Prevention of ovulation

 

Let's explore each option:

 

Option A. Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH (Correct Answer): COCs primarily prevent ovulation. They achieve this by suppressing the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) from the pituitary gland. Without the surge in LH, ovulation does not occur.

 

Option B. Destroying the ovum: COCs do not work by destroying the ovum. They primarily prevent the ovum from being released from the ovary.

 

Option C. Helping prevent implantation by suppressing development of the endometrium: While COCs do cause some thinning of the endometrium, making it less receptive to implantation, this is not their primary mechanism of action. It's more of a secondary effect that contributes to the contraceptive efficacy in case ovulation does occur.

 

Option D. Hampering sperm transport by thickening cervical mucus: This is another secondary mechanism of action of COCs. The progestin component in the COCs thickens the cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to travel through the cervix and into the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary mechanism of action of combined oral contraceptives is the suppression of ovulation through the inhibition of the hormones FSH and LH. Secondary mechanisms, such as alterations in the endometrial lining and thickening of cervical mucus, further enhance their contraceptive effectiveness. Top of Form

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Once a week
Twice a week
Once a week for 12 weeks followed by twice a week from the 13th week onwards
Twice a week for 12 weeks followed by once a week from the 13th week onwards

questions.text: Dosage of Centchroman for contraception is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Twice a week for 12 weeks followed by once a week from the 13th week onwards

 

Explanation:

 

  • Centchroman is ormeloxifene
  • It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)
  • Developed by the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow
  • It is a non – hormonal, synthetic contraceptive
  • Low cost
  • Initially marketed as Saheli and now as Chhaya by the Govt of India
  • Contains 30 mg
  • Recommended dose: 1 tablet twice weekly from the 1st day of menstruation for 3 months followed by once a week
  • 99% effective

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centchroman (Ormeloxifene) is administered as part of a specific dosing regimen for contraception, starting with twice a week for the first 12 weeks, followed by a maintenance dose of once a week from the 13th week onwards.

 

Ref: Page no 278, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Cervical cancer
Colorectal cancer
Endometrial cancer
Ovarian cancer

questions.text: Combined oral contraceptive pills are associated with a decreased risk of all the following cancers except?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Cervical cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers
    • Endometrial
    • Ovarian
    • Colorectal
  • Oral contraceptives increase the risk of 2 cancers
    • Breast
    • Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence)
    • Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas

 

Let us look at each option separately:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer (Correct Answer): The use of COCs has been linked with an increased risk of cervical cancer. This risk appears to increase with the duration of COC use and declines after cessation of use. The increased risk is thought to be related to the role of human papillomavirus (HPV) in cervical carcinogenesis, with COCs possibly affecting the body's immune response to HPV or the progression of HPV infection to cervical cancer.

 

Option B. Colorectal Cancer: Several studies have shown a reduced risk of colorectal cancer in women who use COCs. The mechanism behind this protective effect is not fully understood .

 

Option C. Endometrial Cancer: COCs have been consistently associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer. This protective effect is believed to be due to the progestin component of COCs, which opposes the proliferative effect of estrogen on the endometrium and reduces the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent malignancy.

 

Option D. Ovarian Cancer: Use of COCs has also been linked to a decreased risk of ovarian cancer. The risk reduction appears to be substantial and increases with the duration of use. This protective effect is thought to be related to the suppression of ovulation that occurs with COC use, as each ovulation event is a potential opportunity for malignant transformation in the ovarian epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers
    • Endometrial
    • Ovarian
    • Colorectal
  • Oral contraceptives increase the risk of 2 cancers
    • Breast
    • Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence)
    • Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas

 

Ref: Page no 401, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Less incidence of hemorrhage
Higher success rate
Non invasive
Less incidence of PID

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2P1L1 at 8 weeks pregnancy wants a medical termination of pregnancy for failure of contraception. She wants to know the advantages of medical abortion over surgical methods. All are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Higher success rate

Explanation:

Advantages of medical abortion:

  1. Lesser incidence of haemorrhage, PID, perforation, long term sequelae like subfertility, cervical insufficiency and Asherman syndrome
  2. Non invasive
  3. No anesthesia required

Disadvantages of medical abortion: 

1. Success rate less than surgical abortion (95-99% with medical abortion; almost 100% with surgical evacuation)

2. Takes about 2 weeks for completion (Surgical procedure is quicker and gets done in a 15-30 minutes. 

 

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Less incidence of hemorrhage is an advantage of medical MTP
  • Option C: Non invasive: is an advantage of medical MTP
  • Option D: Less incidence of PID: Is an advantage of medical MTP

Educational Objective: 

Advantages of medical abortion:

  1. Lesser incidence of haemorrhage, PID, perforation, long term sequelae like subfertility, cervical insufficiency and Asherman syndrome
  2. Non invasive
  3. No anesthesia required

Disadvantages of medical abortion: 

1. Success rate less than surgical abortion (95-99% with medical abortion; almost 100% with surgical evacuation)

2. Takes about 2 weeks for completion (Surgical procedure is quicker and gets done in a 15-30 minutes. 

 

Ref: page no 361; William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Colposcopy
Remove the LNG-IUS
Reassure the patient
Ultrasound for endometrial thickness

questions.text: A 38y woman opts for LNG-IUS for contraception. After 6 months she reports back to the OPD with complaints of periods of amenorrhea with irregular spotting. She had previous regular cycles and a pap smear done prior to insertion of the LNG-IUS was normal. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Reassure the patient 

 

Explanation

 

  • LNG-IUS is a 3rd generation Intrauterine device
  • It contains levonorgestrel and mainly acts by causing endometrial atrophy
  • A common side effect is amenorrhoea and irregular spotting for which only reassurance is required
  • 80% of women are amenorrhoeic by the end of 1 year
  • Effective life: 5 years
  • Failure rate: 0.1%

 

**Since pap smear was normal 6 months back, there is no indication for a colposcopy

 

** There is no indication to remove the LNG-IUS

 

**USG for endometrial thickness is not required as this is a known side effect of LNG-IUS

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Colposcopy: This is a diagnostic procedure to examine the cervix for signs of disease, typically indicated if there are abnormal findings on a Pap smear. Since the patient had a normal Pap smear prior to the insertion of the LNG-IUS and her current symptoms are related to menstrual changes, colposcopy is not indicated in this case.

 

Option B. Remove the LNG-IUS: Removal of the LNG-IUS is generally reserved for situations where there are serious complications or persistent, unacceptable side effects. Irregular spotting and periods of amenorrhea are common and expected side effects of the LNG-IUS, especially in the first 6 to 12 months of use.

 

Option C. Reassure the patient (Correct Answer): The most appropriate step in this scenario is to reassure the patient. The LNG-IUS releases levonorgestrel locally within the uterus, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining and result in changes to menstrual bleeding patterns, including lighter periods, irregular spotting, or amenorrhea. These changes are considered normal side effects of the LNG-IUS and often stabilize within the first year of use.

 

Option D. Ultrasound for Endometrial Thickness: While ultrasound can be used to assess endometrial thickness, it is not typically indicated in this scenario unless there are other symptoms or clinical findings suggestive of endometrial pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irregular spotting and episodes of amenorrhea are common side effects of the Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) and usually stabilize within the first year of use. These effects are due to the local action of levonorgestrel on the endometrium. Patients experiencing these changes without other concerning symptoms can generally be reassured about the normalcy of these side effects.

 

Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Take both the missed tablets immediately, use additional contraceptive method for 7 days and advise emergency contraception
Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days and omit the 7-day pill free period
Use emergency contraception and continue taking the remaining pills
Use emergency contraception and discard the remaining pills.

questions.text: An 18y unmarried girl has been using Mala N as a contraceptive method. She comes to the family planning OPD on Day 24 of her period with the complaint that she has missed taking the pills on Day 22 and 23. She is extremely worried and anxious about the risk of conceiving as she had unprotected intercourse on Day 6. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days and omit the 7- day pill free period

 

Explanation: Missing a pill increases the risk of pregnancy.

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

** In this question, she has missed 2 pills in the 3rd week. Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception and omit the pill free interval and start the next pack immediately after finishing the current pack.

 

Here's an explanation of the options:

 

Option A. Take both the missed tablets immediately, use an additional contraceptive method for 7 days, and advise emergency contraception: Taking both missed pills at once is not necessary and may increase the risk of side effects like nausea. Emergency contraception is not typically recommended in this scenario.

 

Option B. Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days, and omit the 7-day pill-free period (Correct Answer): This is the recommended action for missing two consecutive pills in the third week of the cycle. She should take the most recently missed pill as soon as possible (even if it means taking two pills in one day) and then continue with the rest of the pack as normal, without taking a 7-day pill-free break. Using an additional contraceptive method, like condoms, for the next 7 days is important to ensure protection against pregnancy.

 

Option C. Use emergency contraception and continue taking the remaining pills: Emergency contraception is usually not necessary if the missed pills are managed correctly, as described in option B. However, if there is significant concern about pregnancy risk or if the guidance for missed pills is not followed correctly, emergency contraception could be considered.

 

Option D. Use emergency contraception and discard the remaining pills: Discarding the remaining pills is not advised. Instead, she should continue taking her pills as per the guidance for missed pills to maintain contraceptive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of missing two consecutive combined oral contraceptive pills in the third week, the recommended approach is to take the last missed pill as soon as possible (ignoring the earlier missed pill), continue taking the remaining pills as scheduled, use an additional contraceptive method for the next 7 days, and skip the 7-day pill-free break. This approach helps maintain contraceptive protection and reduces the risk of pregnancy due to the missed pills. Emergency contraception is typically not necessary if these steps are followed.

 

Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011. http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf (Accessed 19th August 2021)

choices.text: Combined oral contraceptive pills
Centchroman
LNG-IUS
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate

questions.text: A 24y woman comes to the gyn OPD seeking contraceptive advice. She is married and has a 4-year-old son. She is a known epileptic and is on lamotrigine. Which of the following contraceptives will require you to increase the dose of lamotrigine?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Combined oral contraceptive pills

 

Explanation

 

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills induce lamotrigene metabolism, thereby reducing plasma levels.
  • Women taking OCPs and on lamotrigene are advised to increase the dose of lamotrigine

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (Correct Answer): Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and a progestin. Estrogen can increase the metabolism of lamotrigine, potentially lowering its levels in the blood and reducing its effectiveness. Therefore, if a woman on lamotrigine chooses to use COCs, her lamotrigine dosage may need to be adjusted to maintain seizure control.

 

Option B. Centchroman: This is a non-steroidal, non-hormonal contraceptive, known also as Ormeloxifene. It works as a selective estrogen receptor modulator and is unlikely to interact with lamotrigine.

 

Option C. LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System): The LNG-IUS, such as Mirena, releases levonorgestrel directly into the uterus. The systemic absorption of levonorgestrel is minimal compared to oral contraceptives, and it is unlikely to significantly interact with lamotrigine.

 

Option D. Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA): DMPA is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive. Progestin-only methods are less likely to interact with lamotrigine compared to estrogen-containing methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a woman with epilepsy on lamotrigine therapy, the use of combined oral contraceptive pills may necessitate an adjustment in the lamotrigine dosage due to estrogen-induced increased metabolism of lamotrigine. Non-hormonal methods like Centchroman or progestin-only methods like the LNG-IUS and DMPA are less likely to interact with lamotrigine and are generally safer options in terms of drug interactions for women with epilepsy.

 

Ref:  Epilepsy in Pregnancy Green-top Guideline No. 68 June 2016 ( RCOG )

choices.text: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days
Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet

questions.text: A 23y woman is taking Oral Contraceptive Pills regularly since the past 2 years. She presents to the family planning OPD on Day 8 of her menstrual cycle with the complaint that she has missed taking the pill on Day 7. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet

 

Explanation

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

Let's look  at all the  options:

 

Option A. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet (Correct Answer): This is the recommended advice for a single missed pill. She should take the missed pill as soon as she remembers, even if this means taking two pills in one day. The risk of pregnancy is low with only one missed pill, especially if she has been taking the pills regularly for a long time. She can then continue taking the rest of the pills in the packet as usual.

 

Option B. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also: Emergency contraception is not necessary for a single missed pill, provided she resumes taking her pills as advised.

 

Option C. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days: Using additional contraception for 7 days is the standard advice if two or more pills are missed consecutively, especially in the first week of the pack. However, for a single missed pill, this extra precaution is not typically necessary.

 

Option D. Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet: This advice is excessive for a single missed pill. There is no need to discard the remaining pills or use emergency contraception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman misses a single combined oral contraceptive pill, the best course of action is to take the missed pill as soon as possible and then continue taking the rest of the pills in the packet as scheduled. Additional measures such as emergency contraception or extended use of barrier methods are not necessary for a single missed pill.

 

Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011. http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf (Accessed 19th August 2021)

choices.text: CuT380A
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate
Norplant
Triphasic pill

questions.text: All are examples of Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Triphasic pill

 

Explanation:

 

  • Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) methods are defined as methods requiring administration less than once cycle/ month
  • LARC methods include
    • Intrauterine devices
    • Progesterone implants
    • Injectable contraceptives
  • They require a single act of motivation for long term use eliminating adherence and user dependence

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. CuT380A: This is a Copper T 380A intrauterine device (IUD), a type of LARC. It can provide up to 10 years of contraception. The device is placed inside the uterus and works by releasing copper, which is toxic to sperm.

 

Option B. Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA): DMPA is an injectable form of contraception, commonly known as Depo-Provera. It is administered every three months and is considered a LARC because of its prolonged duration of action and the minimal requirement for user adherence.

 

Option C. Norplant: Norplant, which is no longer available in many countries but has similar successors like Jadelle, consists of implantable rods that release a progestin. This method is a LARC, providing effective contraception for several years.

 

Option D. Triphasic Pill (Correct Answer): The triphasic pill is a form of combined oral contraceptive pill (COC). It is not a LARC; it requires daily administration and adherence by the user. The "triphasic" refers to the varying levels of hormones in the pills over the course of the cycle to mimic the natural menstrual cycle more closely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) methods include devices and formulations like the CuT380A IUD, Depo-Provera injections, and implantable progestin rods (e.g., Norplant, Jadelle), which provide effective contraception for an extended period with minimal need for user action. In contrast, the triphasic pill, a type of combined oral contraceptive, requires daily administration and does not fall under the category of LARC

 

Ref: Page no. 697, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 1st edition

questions.text: A couple approaches the gyn OPD as they are worried about an act of unprotected intercourse and the chances of pregnancy. They have heard about Yuzpe regime. What does this regime contain?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 2 doses of OCPs (Each dose containing 100 mcg of EE) 12h apart

 

Explanation

  • Yuzpe regime is 2 doses of OCPs (Each dose containing 100 mcg of EE) 12h apart; it can be given within 72h of an act of unprotected intercourse; not commonly used because of the vomiting associated with such high dose.

Educational Objective: 

  •  emergency contraceptives available

 

 

Thus, option A.) 2 doses of OCPs (Each dose containing 100 mcg of EE) 12h apart is correct.

 

Educational Objective: The Yuzpe regimen involves taking two doses of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), with each dose containing a high amount of ethinyl estradiol (EE) and a progestin, 12 hours apart. This method can be used within 72 hours (3 days) after unprotected intercourse to reduce the risk of pregnancy.

choices.text: With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months.
With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week.
The progestin only minipill does not affect lactation.
The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breast feeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation.

questions.text: All are true regarding postpartum contraception except:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breast feeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation. 

 

Explanation:

 

  • The use of vaginal estrogen preparation is discouraged because absorption of estrogen can lead to inhibition of milk production.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months: This is true. Lactational amenorrhea, is a common and natural form of contraception in the initial months postpartum. However, it's important to note that its effectiveness as a contraceptive method varies and should be considered in the context of exclusive breastfeeding and frequency of nursing.

 

Option B. With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week: This is generally correct. For women who are not fully breastfeeding, fertility can return earlier, and it's advisable to start a contraceptive method by the third postpartum week to prevent unintended pregnancy.

 

Option C. The progestin-only minipill does not affect lactation: True. Progestin-only contraceptives, like the minipill, are preferred during breastfeeding as they do not affect milk supply. These are safe to use in the postpartum period, including for women who are breastfeeding.

 

Option D. The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breastfeeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation (Incorrect Statement): This statement is not accurate. The vaginal ring typically contains both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives, including the vaginal ring, can potentially reduce breast milk supply and are generally not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially in the early postpartum period. While the systemic absorption may be lower than oral methods, the potential impact on lactation is still a concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postpartum contraception, it's important to choose methods that are safe and effective for the mother, especially if she is breastfeeding. Progestin-only methods like the minipill are preferred during lactation as they do not affect milk supply.

 

Ref: page no 878, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility

choices.text: Hysteroscopy
No need of removal
IUCD hook
Laparoscopy

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 had a Cu T inserted 2 years back. She comes for a checkup as she cant feel the threads. On examination Cu T threads are not seen. USG shows Cu T partly in abdominal cavity. Method of removal is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Laparoscopy

 

  • Copper can cause inflammatory reaction and can cause intestinal obstruction. Therefore, it needs removal.
  • When CuT is embedded within uterine cavity, hysteroscopic removal is the method of choice. It is preferred over IUCD hook as it is removed under direct visualization. But initial removal can be attempted in the OPD with an IUCD hook.
  • When IUCD enters the abdominal cavity (partly or completely), laparoscopy is the preferred modality for retrieval. Sometimes due to dense adhesions around Cu T, a laparotomy may be required to remove it.

 

 

  • In the above flowchart, please note that initially an ultrasound is done to see if the IUCD is in the uterine cavity or not.
  • If it is not seen in the uterine cavity, then to confirm it is in the abdomen, an Xray (with a sound in the uterus) is done.

 

Let's examine each option:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: This is a procedure where a hysteroscope  is inserted into the uterus through the cervix. It's used for diagnosing and treating intrauterine conditions. However, if the Cu T is in the abdominal cavity, hysteroscopy would not be appropriate or effective for removal.

 

Option B. No need for removal: Leaving an IUD in the abdominal cavity is not advisable. It can lead to complications such as adhesions, perforation of other organs, or chronic pain. Therefore, removal is typically recommended.

 

Option C. IUCD Hook: An IUCD hook is used for retrieving IUD threads when they are within the cervical canal or the uterine cavity but not visible at the external os. Since the Cu T is in the abdominal cavity in this scenario, an IUCD hook would not be helpful.

 

Option D. Laparoscopy (Correct Answer): Laparoscopy is a surgical procedure that uses a small incision and a camera to look inside the abdominal cavity. It's the most appropriate method for retrieving an IUD that has migrated into the abdominal cavity. This approach is minimally invasive and allows for the safe removal of the IUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an IUD is dislodged from the uterus and located in the abdominal cavity, laparoscopic surgery is the preferred method for removal. This minimally invasive procedure allows for direct visualization and retrieval of the IUD, minimizing the risk of injury to abdominal and pelvic organs

 

Ref: Page no 484 DC Duttas textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Start next cycle of tablets immediately
Start next cycle from next day
Urine pregnancy test
Wait for another 1 weeks for period

questions.text: Seema, a 32-year mother of 2 children, has been on Mala N for contraception. After the end of the first strip. there was no withdrawal bleeding. It has now been 7 days since the last tablet and she visits you.  What should be done?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Urine pregnancy test

 

Explanation:

 

  • The first thing that needs to be ruled out is pregnancy.
  • Hence UPT needs to be done.
  • IF UPT is negative, she can start a new packet of OCPs,

 

Let's explore the options:

 

Option A. Start next cycle of tablets immediately: While it's generally recommended to start the next pack of pills after the usual pill-free interval (or placebo pill week), doing so without addressing the absence of withdrawal bleeding could potentially overlook an early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Start next cycle from next day: Similar to option A, this does not address the underlying concern of potential pregnancy. It's important to rule out pregnancy before continuing with the next cycle of contraceptive pills.

 

Option C. Urine Pregnancy Test (Correct Answer): The absence of withdrawal bleeding at the end of a contraceptive pill cycle can be a sign of pregnancy, especially if the pills were not taken consistently or correctly. A urine pregnancy test (UPT) is a simple and effective way to rule out or confirm pregnancy before proceeding with further contraceptive use.

 

Option D. Wait for another 1 week for period: While waiting could be an option, it might delay the identification of a potential pregnancy. Given that the patient is already at the end of her pill-free interval, it's more proactive to perform a pregnancy test to promptly address any potential pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills does not experience withdrawal bleeding, a pregnancy test should be performed to rule out the possibility of pregnancy, especially if there is any chance of inconsistent pill use. This is a critical step before starting a new pack of contraceptive pills.

 

Ref: Page no 488, DC Duttas textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Endometrial Carcinoma
Endometrial hyperplasia
Molar pregnancy
Retained product of conception

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits OPD with heavy menstrual bleeding. Her USG is shown below Histopathology shows dilated cystic glands with increased gland: stroma ratio. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endometrial hyperplasia

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition where there is endometrial thickening. It can be simple pr complex and with or without atypia.
  • Simple hyperplasia is characterized by dilated or cystic glands with round to slightly irregular shapes, an increased glandular-to-stromal ratio without glandular crowding
  • Complex hyperplasia has architecturally complex (budding and infolding) crowded glands, with less intervering stroma
  • Atypical hyperplasia refers to cytologic atypia and is a high risk for endometrial carcinoma

Other Options

  1. Option A: Endometrial cancer: In this the HPE will show features of carcinoma including  cellular / nuclear enlargement, nuclear rounding with large nucleoli, loss of polarity and cytoplasmic eosinophilia
  2. Option C: Molar Pregnancy: The USG image will show snowstorm appearance and the HPE will show, trophoblastic hyperplasia and villous edema
  3. Option D: Retained products of conception: This will appear as trophoblastic tissue on microscopy

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition where there is endometrial thickening. It can be simple pr complex and with or without atypia.
  • Simple hyperplasia is characterized by dilated or cystic glands with round to slightly irregular shapes, an increased glandular-to-stromal ratio without glandular crowding
  • Complex hyperplasia has architecturally complex (budding and infolding) crowded glands, with less intervering stroma
  • Atypical hyperplasia refers to cytologic atypia and is a high risk for endometrial carcinoma

 

Ref: berek & novak, 16 ed, page 2364

choices.text: Cervarix
Cervavac
Gardasil
Gardasil 9

questions.text: A P4L4, 43-year-old woman presents to OPD with post coital bleeding. On cervical biopsy, she is found to have CIN III. You counsel her about her treatment and also guide her for preventive strategy for her 2 daughters (17 years, 12-year-old) with HPV vaccine. Which of the following is the indigenous cervical cancer vaccine soon to be available in India by serum institute of India:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervavac
 

Ref: https://isccp.in/cervavac-the-new-buzz/
 

The National Cancer Institute of the US National Institute of Health (NIH) reports that three vaccines are currently being offered in numerous nations all over the world to prevent infection with the disease-causing HPV. These include Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil 9.
 

The vaccines Cervarix is bivalent, Gardasil 9 is nonavalent, and Gardasil is quadrivalent. This translates to four, nine, and two HPV strains in Gardasil, Gardasil 9, and Cervarix, respectively.
 

HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18 are prevented by Gardasil, while HPV types 16 and 18 are prevented by Cervarix.
Infection with HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 is prevented with Gardasil 9.
 

Cervavac: Tetravalent or quadrivalent L1 virus-like particles (VLPs) of serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18 are part of the serum institute of India (SII)’s HPV vaccination.

choices.text: HPV testing should be used as a method of cancer cervix screening after 25 years of age

questions.text: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) is the causative agent in majority of cervical cancers. Which of the following is TRUE in relation to HPV testing as per WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans: C: Interval of 5-10 years is recommended when using HPV as primary screening

Explanation: 

  • WHO recommends starting regular cervical cancer screening at the age of 30 years among the general population of women.
  • WHO recommends using HPV DNA detection as the primary screening test rather than VIA or cytology in screening and treatment approaches among both the general population of women and women living with HIV
  • WHO suggests a regular screening interval of every 5 to 10 years when using HPV DNA detection as the primary screening test among the general population of women
  • After the age of 50 years, WHO suggests screening is stopped after two consecutive negative screening results consistent with the recommended regular screening intervals among both the general population of women and women living with HIV

Other options: 

  • Option A: HPV testing should be used as a method of cancer cervix screening after 25 years of age: This is incorrect as screening with HPV should start at age 30 
  • Option B: HPV should only be used in adjunct with either Pap’s smear or liquid based cytology: This is also incorrect. As per WHO, HPV alone is the preferred screening test
  • Option D: Women with previous 2 HPV screen negative can stop screening after the age of 60 years: This is also incorrect. After the age of 50 years, WHO suggests screening is stopped after two consecutive negative screening results consistent with the recommended regular screening intervals among both the general population of women and women living with HIV

Educational Objective: 

 

  • WHO recommends starting regular cervical cancer screening at the age of 30 years among the general population of women.
  • WHO recommends using HPV DNA detection as the primary screening test rather than VIA or cytology in screening and treatment approaches among both the general population of women and women living with HIV
  • WHO suggests a regular screening interval of every 5 to 10 years when using HPV DNA detection as the primary screening test among the general population of women
  • After the age of 50 years, WHO suggests screening is stopped after two consecutive negative screening results consistent with the recommended regular screening intervals among both the general population of women and women living with HIV

 

Ref: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition, 2021

questions.text: Identify the procedure done with the instrument given:
questions.solution:
Ans: B: Cytobrush for Liquid based cytology

Berek and novak 16th edition, page number 925

The ubiquitous use of liquid-based medium to collect the cytologic sample and preserve the collected cervical cells significantly decreased specimen sampling and preparation errors.

With this technique, liquid samples areprocessed to provide a uniform, thin layer of cervical cells without debris on a glass slide. The cell sample is collected with an endocervical brush used in combination with a plastic spatula or with a plastic broom. The sample is rinsed in a vial containing liquid alcohol-based preservative. With this technique, 80% to 90% of the cells are transferred to the liquid media, as compared with the 10% to 20% transferred to the glass slide with conventional cytologic testing. Use of liquid-based media eliminates air drying. The cells are retrieved from the vial by passing the liquid through a filter, which traps the larger epithelial cells, separating them from the small blood and inflammatory cells. This process yields a thin layer of diagnostic cells properly preserved and more easily interpreted by the cytologist. This technique reduces by 70% to 90% the rate of unsatisfactory samples encountered with conventional cytologic testing

 

Ref: DC dutta textbook of gynaecology page no: 627

Recent update in WHO,2021

Ref: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition, 2021

WHO recommends using HPV DNA detection as the primary screening test rather than VIA or cytology in screening and treatment approaches among both the general population of women and women living with HIV.

Existing programmes with quality-assured cytology as the primary screening test should be continued until HPV DNA testing is operational; existing programmes using VIA as the primary screening should transition rapidly because of the inherent challenges with quality assurance.

questions.text: A 55 years old P5L5 presented to OPD with postcoital bleeding and vaginal discharge. On examination, there is a 3 x 3cm growth involving the entire cervix. The growth does not seem to extend to the vagina and the parametrium is free. Which of the following investigations can be used for staging of cancer cervix:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

In 2018, the FIGO (Federation of International Gynecologists and Obstetricians) Gynecologic Oncology Committee revised the staging to allow the option of clinical, radiological, or pathological findings, as available, to assign the stage. FIGO 2018 staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

 

MRI is the best method of radiologic assessment of primary tumors greater than 10 mm.

 

The stage is allocated after all imaging and pathology reports are available. It is not to be altered later, for example at recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cervical cancer is primarily a clinical staging but FIGO 2018 staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

 

Ref  : FIGO cancer report 2021

questions.text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal  What is the next best step?

Explanation:

  • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.

  • Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: A 27-year woman who is anxious to conceive visits the OPD with her husband. They have been trying to conceive for 2 years. She has regular periods with heavy flow. There is associated dysmenorrhea. A transvaginal scan shows a submucosal fibroid of about 2 cm in size. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Explanation:

This patient is infertile and has a submucosal fibroid. The fibroid has to be removed. Type 0 and 1 submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically

Other Options

  • Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed.
  • Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility. 

Educational Objective:

  • Indications of myomectomy in infertility are:
    • Submucous fibroids
    • Large intramural fibroids distorting the cavity.
    • Intramural fibroids > 5cm
  • Submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically (Esp type 0 and type 1)

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Copper intrauterine device
Combination oral contraceptives (COCs)

Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS)

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following are appropriate medical treatments for adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Copper intrauterine device

Explanation

  • Adenomyosis can be managed medically
    • NSAIDs
    • Anti-fibrinolytics
    • Combined OCPS
    • LNG-IUS
    • SPRMs
  • Surgical (Hysterectomy) is the definitive treatment of adenomyosis
  • A copper containing IUCD will increase the bleeding and should not be used for adenomyosis

Ectocervical cells
Endometrial glands and stroma
Endocervical glands and stroma

questions.text: With endometriosis, as shown here, which of the following is ectopically located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial glands and stroma

Explanation

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (including glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (including glands and stroma) outside the uterus.
  • The most common site is the ovary where it presents as an endometriotic cyst (Chocolate cyst)

 

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Lymphatic spread
Hormonal induction
Coelomic metaplasia
Retrograde menstruation

questions.text: Which of the following theories is the most widely accepted as the cause of endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Retrograde menstruation

Explanation

The definitive cause of endometriosis remains unknown, but theories have been proposed.

  • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory

All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:

  • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis
  • Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated.
  • Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.

Educational Objective: 

The most common theory of endometriosis is the theory of retrograde menstruation

 

Ref: Page no 231, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Danazol
Aromatase inhibitors
Laparoscopic ablation of lesions
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists

questions.text: Women seeking immediate fertility and who suffer from endometriosis would most likely benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

Explanation:

  • Treatment of endometriosis is by both medical or surgical management
  • If pain is prominent and conception is not currently desired, then medical therapy is typically selected.
    • Available agents include NSAIDs, OCPs, progestins, GnRH agents, and aromatase inhibitors.
    • In general, suitable starting regimens are NSAIDS alone or combined with oral contraceptive pills or with a progestin.
    • Although medical treatment improves pain, relapse rates are high with therapy discontinuation.
  • If infertility is the presenting symptom, then laparoscopic management should be considered (ablation/ excision of endometriotic implants)

 

Ref: Page 265, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Drainage
Cystectomy
Cyst wall ablation
None of the above

questions.text: For surgical treatment of endometriomas, which of the following approaches is superior?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystectomy

Explanation

  • Endometriomas are typically treated surgically to exclude malignancy or treat associated pain.
  • Cystectomy lowers endometrioma recurrence rates and pain symptoms and improves subsequent spontaneous pregnancy rates
  • During surgery, ideally normal ovarian tissue is preserved as much as possible

 

Ref: Page no 269, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Ablation of the lesions
Ovarian cystectomy
Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
Laparoscopic adhesiolysis

questions.text: A 25-year woman is undergoing a diagnostic laparoscopy for unexplained infertility. The following is seen. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ablation of the lesions

 

Explanation

 

  • The black-brown lesions seen on the surface of the ovary are endometriotic lesions
  • Endometriotic lesions like these require to be ablated so that the ectopic endometrium is destroyed
  • Ovarian tissue should not be damaged

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cystectomy: Done for endometrioma, not for surface lesions. there are no endometrioma to be removed in this case

 

Option C. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is not a treatment for endometriosis. It is used for infertility management in PCOS

 

Option D. Laparoscopic adhesiolysis: There are no adhesions in the image. no requirement of adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 264, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Anti-fibrinolytics
Hysterectomy
Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium
Endometrial biopsy

questions.text: A 52y woman who has been menopausal for more than a year presents to the OPD with complains of bleeding since 3 days. She thinks it may be a part of menopause but is a little concerned as she used to have heavy bleeding during her periods several years earlier. She is on anti-hypertensives. On examination, her vitals are stable. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. A speculum exam shows a normal cervix with blood visible at the os. The uterus is normal in size. A transvaginal scan shows an endometrial thickness of 8mm with b/l normal ovaries. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Endometrial biopsy

Explanation

  • This is a woman who is having post-menopausal bleeding (PMB)
  • The most common causes of PMB is endometrial atrophy but also it is important to rule out malignancies in this age group
  • As the cervix appears normal and the TVS shows an increased endometrial thickness (it should be < 5mm in the post-menopausal age group), the next best step would be to take an endometrial biopsy. This can be done by
    • Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration)
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)

Other Options

  • Option A: Antifibrinolytics: This is indicated in women with heavy menstrual bleeding. However in post menopausal bleeding, the main aim is to rule out a malignancy
  • Option B: Hysterectomy: This won't be the initial step. The initial step is to diagnose the cause of post menopsuasal bleeding
  • Option C: Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium: This is a type of endometrial ablation and is recommended in heavy menstrual bleeding. It is however c/i in premalignant and malignant lesions and those need to be ruled out by an endometrial biopsy

Educational Objective: 

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.solution:
Ans: D. Menorrhagia

  • Intra uterine copper device typically causes menorrhagia due to acute inflammatory reaction in the endoemtrium 
  • This usually settles down aftera few cycles

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hysterectomy
Endometrial ablation
Insertion of LNG-IUS
Combined oral contraceptives

questions.text: A 47-year-old P3 presents with heavy bleeding following periods of amenorrhoea. She has been experiencing this symptom on and off since several months now and attributed it to nearing menopause. On examination, her BMI is 30. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination is normal and a bimanual pelvic exam reveals a normal sized uterus. An ultrasound shows a thickened endometrium for which she undergoes an office biopsy. This shows endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. The best treatment option for her is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Insertion of LNG-IUS

  • The LNG-IUS (Mirena) is the first-line medical treatment of simple endometrial hyperplasia (without atypia)
  • Continuous progestogens can also be be used (medroxyprogesterone 10–20 mg/day or norethisterone 10–15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS. 
  • Treatment should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • Endometrial surveillance - at a minimum of 6-monthly intervals. 
  • In the presence of atypia, hysterectomy with b/l salpingo-oophorectomy should be done.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Hysterectomy: This is not indicated in the absence of atypia as the risk of malignany is low
  • Option B: Endometrial ablation: This is not indicated in endometrial ablation
  • Option D: Combined OCPs: This is not preferred in endometrial hyperplasia. High dose proegesterone is preferred

Educational Objective:

 

Ref: Green-top Guideline No. 67 RCOG/BSGE Joint Guideline | February 2016  

https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/green-top guidelines/gtg_67_endometrial_hyperplasia.pdf

choices.text: Breastfeeding < 6 weeks postpartum
Uncontrolled Hypertension with BP 150/90 mmHg
History of Cerebrovascular disease
History of Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: All the following fall under Medical Eligibility Criteria 4 of Combined oral contraceptives except?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Uncontrolled Hypertension with BP 150/ 90 mmHg

 

The WHO has defined Medical Eligibility Criteria for using contraceptives. These are

 

 

MEC Category 4 for Combined Oral Contraceptives include:

 

  • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
  • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
  • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/ day
  • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
  • Hypertension with vascular disease
  • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
  •  Acute DVT/ Pulmonary embolism
  • DVT/ Pul embolism on anticoagulant therapy
  • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
  • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g. Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
  • Current and history of ischaemic heart disease
  • Stroke (history of Cerebrovascular disease)
  • Complicated valvular heart disease
  • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
  • Migraine with aura (any age)
  • Current breast cancer
  • Severe cirrhosis
  • Hepatocellular ademona/ carcinoma

 

**Family h/o DVT/ Pul embolism falls under category 3 and not category 4

 

 Let's review each option in this context:

 

Option A. Breastfeeding < 6 weeks postpartum: This falls under Category 4 for combined oral contraceptives (COCs). Estrogen in COCs can reduce milk supply and potentially affect breast milk production . Therefore, their use is generally not recommended for women who are less than 6 weeks postpartum and are breastfeeding.

 

Option B. Uncontrolled Hypertension with BP 150/90 mmHg (Correct Answer): This condition actually falls under Category 3 for COCs, which means that the risks usually outweigh the benefits, but COCs may be used in some circumstances if no better alternatives are available. Controlled hypertension, however, would be a different scenario with different categorization.

 

Option C. History of Cerebrovascular Disease: Women with a history of cerebrovascular disease are categorized under MEC 4 for COCs due to the increased risk of thrombotic events associated with estrogen. The use of COCs could significantly elevate the risk of stroke in these women.

 

Option D. History of Pulmonary Embolism: A personal history of thrombotic events is MEC category 4 . A family history of pulmonary embolism, particularly in first-degree relatives, may indicate a genetic predisposition to thrombotic events but this alone does not typically fall under Category 4 for COCs unless the individual has other risk factors or a personal history of thrombotic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of contraceptive eligibility, certain conditions like breastfeeding less than 6 weeks postpartum and a history of cerebrovascular disease are contraindications (Category 4) for the use of combined oral contraceptives due to the increased risks associated with estrogen. However, uncontrolled hypertension with BP 150/90 mmHg falls under Category 3, where the risks usually outweigh the benefits but may be considered if no better alternatives exist.

 

Ref : WHO  Medical eligibility criteria for contraceptive use (Fifth edition, 2015)

choices.text: Does not need any additional contraceptive
Needs additional contraception for 3 months
Needs additional contraception till a semen analysis shows azoospermia
Needs additional contraception till 1 month

questions.text: A 34y man undergoes a no scalpel vasectomy. What is the post operative advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Needs additional contraception till a semen analysis shows azoospermia

 

Explanation

 

  • After vasectomy, clients can resume sexual activity as soon as it is comfortable for them.
  • This usually takes at least two to three days after the procedure.
  • Counsel clients that vasectomy does not work immediately, and they can still get their partners pregnant.
  • Post vasectomy clients have to use condoms or their partners should use another family planning method consistently and correctly for at least three months.
  • After three months, client should return to the clinic for a semen analysis to make sure that the vasectomy was successful.
  • All vasectomy clients should be provided with instructions and practice on the correct use of condoms for use immediately after the vasectomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • After vasectomy, clients can resume sexual activity as soon as it is comfortable for them.
  • This usually takes at least two to three days after the procedure.
  • Patients should be counseled that vasectomy does not work immediately, and they can still get their partners pregnant.
  • Post vasectomy clients have to use condoms or their partners should use another family planning method consistently and correctly for at least three months.
  • After three months, client should return to the clinic for a semen analysis to make sure that the vasectomy was successful.

 

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/family-planing/guidelines/Reference_Manual_for_Male_Sterilization-NSV-Oct_2013.pdf

questions.text: A woman comes in for an annual gynecologic examination. During speculum examination, you see the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Perform a cervical biopsy.

 

Explanation:

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a lesion is seen, so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

Other options

  • A pap smear is done when there is no visible lesion on the cervix
  • Imaging studies and referral to a gyn oncologist have a role in cervical cancer once a diagnosis is made

Educational Objective:

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a lesion is seen, so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

choices.text: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with preservation of ovaries
Laparoscopic hysterectomy with transposition of ovaries
Radical trachelectomy
Simple trachelectomy

questions.text: Mrs Rina, a 35 year old P1L1 has 1.5 x 1.5cm growth limited to the cervix. A biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinomal of the cervix and an MRI reveals no other involvement of surrounding structures. She wishes to undergo fertility preserving surgery and future childbearing . Which of the following would be an appropriate management for her:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Radical trachelectomy.

  • Radical trachelectomy is a procedure that is gaining popularity as a surgical management option for women with stage 1A2 and IB1 disease who desire uterine preservation and fertility.
  • As this patient would fall into Stage 1 A2, this treatment modality can be offered
  • It is Suitable for tumors less than 2cm size.
  • In radical trachelectomy, the following is removed
    • The cervix
    • Part of parametria and paracolpos
    • Part of uterosacral ligaments
    • 1-2 cm of vaginal cuff
    • Descending cervico-vaginal branch of uterine artery is ligated
    • Permamant encerclage of the cervical stump 
    • Pelvic lymoh nodes

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with preservation of ovaries: This can also be considered in a woman wanting to preserve fertility but she will require a gestational surrogate
  • Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy with transposition of ovaries: Transposition of the ovaris is usually done if the woman is to recieve pelvic radiotherapy
  • Option D: Simple trachelectomy is not an option in early stage cervical cancer. 

Educatiional Objective: 

Radical trachelectomy is a procedure that is gaining popularity as a surgical management option for women with stage 1A2 and IB1 disease who desire uterine preservation and fertility.

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition page 2473
